finalPattern.pattern_name: First-person, apology-led, negatively framed titles that bluntly critique a 'new' artist or trend (e.g., 'I‚Äôm Sorry‚Ä¶This New Artist Completely Sucks') materially outperform Rick Beato‚Äôs baseline by leveraging high-arousal controversy and curiosity to boost CTR and early velocity.

data.statement: Negatively framed, first-person ‚Äòapology + blunt critique‚Äô titles targeting a contemporary or ‚Äúnew‚Äù artist (e.g., ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Sorry‚Ä¶This New Artist Completely Sucks‚Äù) outperform Rick Beato‚Äôs baseline by boosting curiosity- and controversy-driven CTR relative to his usual neutral/educational titles.
data.reasoning: This title uses a high-arousal negative sentiment (‚Äúcompletely sucks‚Äù) plus a curiosity hook (‚ÄúI‚Äôm Sorry‚Ä¶‚Äù) that stands out against the channel‚Äôs typical analytical/neutral framing, likely increasing clicks from both agreement-seeking and debate-seeking viewers. Targeting a ‚Äònew artist‚Äô broadens relevance beyond a single fanbase, reducing alienation and amplifying shareability. The conflict-centric framing invites comments and watch time via rebuttals/defenses, which can further boost distribution. If this hypothesis is correct, similar negative-opinion, first-person titles on this channel (and comparable music-commentary channels) should show higher CTR and TPS than baseline, with at least a medium effect size.
